channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl People with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl Programmer Opportunity - Join a Prominent Tech Publishing Powerhouse in the Philippines
item.description: Our UK-based client is a global leader in the enterprise technology publishing industry, providing audiences worldwide with stimulating perspectives and unique news on enterprise tech that matters today and tomorrow. They are currently seeking a passionate and exceptional Perl programmer based in the Philippines to join their team.

item.title: Getting started with Loco, the one-person web framework for Rust
item.description: It is, or rather will be a Rails (or Catalyst)-like web framework. I tried it and this is what I got so far.

item.title: This Week in Rust
item.description: This is the weekly newsletter for Rust. Just as the Perl Weekly it source is in GitHub, but they also keep the draft of the next edition in GitHub and make it easy for people to contribute links by sending Pull-Requests.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Largest Sort
item.description: Sort by external key is the core point. The end result is worth checking out.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #245
item.description: Smart use CPAN module without any gimmicks. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Popular languages and largest threefold
item.description: One-liner in Perl with detailed discussion. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 245
item.description: Perl one-liner alongwith Schwartzian transform is doing the trick. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Hashes and Joins
item.description: Choice of multipl approach using the power of Raku. You really don't want to skip it.

item.title: THE WEEKLY CHALLENGE - 245
item.description: Blend of Perl, Raku and Python showing the power of individual languages. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 245: Largest of Three
item.description: Just Raku this time showing off the power with plenty of discussion. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 245: Sort Language
item.description: Index slice? Please do checkout the post for more information.

item.title: The Most Popular of Three
item.description: Various type of sort in action. Well documented process, keep it up great work.

item.title: I'm never last picked
item.description: Love the use of CPAN to get the job done. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Getting Things Sorted
item.description: Thanks for sharing the history of Schwartzian Transform. Good job.

item.title: La La Three
item.description: Clever use of combinations and permutations of Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: TWC245
item.description: Self documented one-liner in Perl. Well done.

item.title: Sleeping Threads Reveal the Largest of Three
item.description: Good use of thread in Perl. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 245
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Sort Language" and "Largest of Three" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 246
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "6 out of 49" and "Linear Recurrence of Second Order". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: List of new CPAN distributions – Nov 2023
YAML Script Advent Calendar
item.description: YAMLScript is a new programming language that uses YAML as its syntax. It is a complete, functional, general purpose language, but can also be easily embedded in YAML files to make them dynamic at load time. Most existing YAML files and all JSON files are already valid YAMLScript programs. YAMLScript has a compiler/interpreter CLI program called `ys` and will soon be available as a libyamlscript.so binding module in 42 programming languages including Perl and Raku.

item.title: Raku Advent Calendar
item.description: One post about Raku every day till Christmas.

item.title: Perl Advent
item.description: One post about Perl every day till Christmas.

item.title: Advent Planet
item.description: If you are looking for Advent calendars about Perl or other languages, check out the Adven Calendar that Len Jaffe has been maintaining since 2000.

item.title: The curious case of implicit return
Rust Maven
item.description: I have been writing about Rust for several months and enjoying it a lot. I think it can be an excellent direction for Perl developers who are interested in something else that is very different from Perl. You are invited to subscribe to the Rust Maven newsletter!

item.title: #645 - Advent Calendars
item.description:
Hi there!

Welcome to the new subscribers!

December has arrived and with it the season of the Advent Calendars. You might recall that Len Jaffe has an Advent Calendar aggregator called Advent Planet. If you know a running calendar that is not listed there, please contact Len!

It lists the Perl Advent Calendar and the Raku advent calendar, and a few more. Ingy dot Net pointed to the YAML Script Advent Calendar.

In the previous edition Mohammad sent a call to get sponsor for his Weekly programming challenge. Several people replied to me. Those messages were forwarded to Mohammad as that is his gig. However, I noticed that the link we used to have at the top of the Perl Weekly was only showing up on the web site. I added it back. In a nutshell, if you'd like to spoonsor/financially help the work of Mohammad S Anwar then either contact him or just support him via Patreon. If you'd like to support my work then you can do so either via Patreon or vi GitHub.

Enjoy your week!

Gabor
item.dc:subject: editorial
